abstract.p: PricewaterhouseCoopers warns that seven of Britain's 28 publicly traded Internet companies could run out of cash in next sixth months, and fewer than half have enough cash to last through next 15 months, even factoring in 130 percent annual growth described as typical for Internet commerce (M)

block.p: In the wake of the collapse last week of Boo.com, a high-profile European Internet retailer, a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers warned that 7 of Britain's 28 publicly traded Internet companies could run out of cash in the next six months, while fewer than half had enough cash to last through the next 15 months.

The study calculated the companies' ''burn rate'' based on their latest reported balance-sheet cash, gross profits and cash expenses, and factored in 130 percent annual growth, described as typical for Internet commerce. No link was found between a company's burn rate and the performance of its stock.

The study calculated the companies' ''burn rate'' based on their latest reported balance-sheet cash, gross profits and cash expenses, and factored in 130 percent annual growth, described as typical for Internet commerce. No link was found between a company's burn rate and the performance of its stock.
